awd_titl_txt: 2018 Gene Golub SIAM Summer School: Inverse Problems: Systematic Integration of Data with Models under Uncertainty
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the participation of US-based PhD students in the 2018 Gene Golub Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (SIAM) Summer School entitled "Inverse Problems: Systematic Integration of Data with Models under Uncertainty," taking place June 17-30, 2018 in Breckenridge, Colorado. The fundamental question addressed by this two-week summer school is: How do we optimally learn from data through the lens of models? And how do we do so when the data and models are uncertain (as they usually are)? These questions have become central with the massive explosion of data volumes across all areas of science, engineering, technology, medicine, and the social sciences. The summer school aims to introduce graduate students to the mathematical and computational aspects of such inverse problems, particularly modern developments that emphasize the quantification of uncertainty in the inverse solution within the framework of Bayesian inference. 

The summer school brings graduate students together with experts in foundational areas of Bayesian inverse problems. The lectures feature an integrated format that begins with ill-posedness and regularization, develops the ideas and tools for deterministic inversion via numerical optimization, and elaborates formulations and solution methods for the modern Bayesian perspective, building on several of the deterministic tools. The focus throughout the lectures is on methods that can scale to inverse problems governed by complex forward models, such as partial differential equations. Morning lectures are complemented by afternoon hands-on laboratory sessions using open-source software (hippylib and MUQ) that implements state-of-the-art deterministic and Bayesian inversion methods, and the school concludes with student project presentations. The summer school aims to augment existing academic curricula with instruction in Bayesian inverse problems that reflects the relatively recent emergence of the mathematical and computational foundations of the field, the need to integrate concepts from inverse theory, partial differential equations, optimization, probability, statistics, and computing, and the need to develop supporting software. This perspective is critical to maximizing the information gained from data when interpreted via models.

More information can be found at
https://www.siam.org/students/g2s3/index.php

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 2018 Gene Golub SIAM Summer School was held June 17-30, 2018 in Breckenridge, Colorado, USA, on the theme of Inverse Problems: Systematic Integration of Data with Models under Uncertainty. The goal of the summer school was to introduce graduate students to the mathematical and computational aspects of inverse problems, particularly modern developments that emphasize the quantification of uncertainty in the inverse solution within the framework of Bayesian inference. Inverse theory and algorithms play a critical role in contemporary science and engineering as a rational and systematic framework for integrating ever-expanding volumes of observational data with increasingly complex models to reduce uncertainty in the predictions of these models. 

The two-week summer school was sponsored by SIAM through its Gene Golub summer school endowment. The theme of Bayesian inverse problems proved to be very popular, with 257 applications submitted from students around the world, of whom only 44 could be accepted due to funding and meeting space limitations. The funds provided by NSF were used to support the airfare and lodging of 13 graduate students from U.S. institutions. The accepted students formed a highly diverse group, with respect to gender (16 women), geography (with 27 students coming from institutions in the U.S. and 17 from institutions in 11 other countries), and areas of study (spanning applied mathematics, statistics, engineering, and natural sciences). 

The summer school featured an integrated and coherent presentation that began with ill-posedness and regularization, developed the ideas and tools for deterministic inversion via adjoint-based sensitivity analysis and numerical optimization, and finally elaborated formulations and sampling-based solution methods for the modern Bayesian perspective, building on several of the deterministic tools. The concepts introduced in the morning lectures were put into practice and explored in depth in afternoon hands-on laboratory sessions using powerful open-source software (hIPPYlib, MUQ) implementing state-of-the-art deterministic and Bayesian inversion methods. In the last several days of the school, the students worked together in small teams on research projects that employed the theory, algorithms, and software they learned to tackle realistic and challenging inverse problems of their own choosing or selected from a provided list. The teams presented their projects on the last day of the summer school. 

The installation and use of the hIPPYlib and MUQ software libraries was greatly eased through their deployment on an NSF XSEDE cloud system (Jetstream), delivered via Docker containerization. Lab sessions featured cloud-based interactive tutorials in the form of Jupyter notebooks, which mixed instruction and theory with editable and runnable code. The Jupyter notebooks allowed students to run and modify the illustrative codes through their web browsers, permitting rapid experimentation with different inverse problem formulations, discretizations, and solution algorithms. To broaden the impact of the summer school beyond those who attended, all lab material, including 16 tutorials and associated code, is freely available on the summer school website (at http://g2s3.com/labs/index.html). 

Breckenridge was chosen for the location of the summer school because mid-to-late June is still the off season in the Colorado Rockies, and we were able to obtain (quite low) government rates on hotel rooms and food, as well as free meeting space. The secluded mountain environment provided a relaxed and inspiring atmosphere that was highly conducive to learning, exchange of ideas, and collaboration. The use of a dedicated Slack workspace facilitated communication between instructors and students, and among students, allowing them to collaborate and interact scientifically as well as socially. In an exit survey, 87.5% of students gave the summer school an overall rating of 5/5, with another 10% rating it 4/5, suggesting that the 2018 G2S3 was viewed very favorably. 

More information about the 2018 Gene Golub SIAM Summer School can be read at: https://sinews.siam.org/Details-Page/students-tackle-bayesian-inverse-problems-in-the-colorado-rockies.
